questions.question: What is the standard length of a croquet court?

correctTheory.title: Court Dimensions
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.summary: The standard length of a croquet court is 35 yards, a measurement crucial for proper court setup and consistent play.
correctTheory.significance: Essential for maintaining standardized court layouts worldwide
correctTheory.related_concepts: Court dimensions, layout specifications, playing area

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Law 2

questions.question: Who was responsible for standardizing the rules of croquet in 1866-67?

correctTheory.title: Early Standardization of Croquet
correctTheory.author: Croquet Association
correctTheory.key_concepts: Rule standardization, game development, historical figures
correctTheory.summary: Walter Jones Whitmore played a crucial role in standardizing croquet rules in 1866-67.
correctTheory.significance: First major standardization of croquet rules
correctTheory.related_concepts: Game history, rule development, standardization

questions.citation: Croquet Association Archives, Early Rule Development Records (1866-1867)

questions.question: What is a triple peel in croquet?

answers.answer: Running three hoops in one turn
Making another ball score its last three hoops
Scoring three points in one turn

correctTheory.title: Advanced Break Play
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Triple peel, break play, advanced tactics
correctTheory.summary: Making another ball score its last three hoops is the definition of a triple peel. This advanced tactic is distinct from simply running three hoops with your own ball or hitting multiple balls in sequence.
correctTheory.significance: Advanced tactic for game completion
correctTheory.related_concepts: Break play, peeling, advanced strategy

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Glossary

questions.question: What happens after a roquet is made?

correctTheory.title: Basic Shot Sequence
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.summary: After a roquet (hitting another ball), the 'striker gets a croquet shot'. The turn does not end, the ball is not removed, and the opponent does not take the next shot. Instead, the striker must take their croquet shot with the two balls in contact.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental rule of gameplay sequence
correctTheory.related_concepts: Shot sequence, basic rules, turn structure

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Law 17

questions.question: What scoring system is used in the MacRobertson Shield?

correctTheory.title: International Tournament Formats
correctTheory.author: Croquet Association
correctTheory.key_concepts: Tournament formats, international competition, test matches
correctTheory.summary: The MacRobertson Shield uses a 'test match format'. Teams compete over multiple days in a series of matches, similar to cricket test matches, rather than using best-of series or single game knockouts.
correctTheory.significance: Most prestigious team event in world croquet
correctTheory.related_concepts: Team competition, international croquet, tournament structure

questions.citation: World Croquet Federation Tournament Regulations

questions.question: Who won the first MacRobertson Shield in 1925?

correctTheory.title: MacRobertson Shield History
correctTheory.author: Croquet Association
correctTheory.key_concepts: International competition, team events, tournament history
correctTheory.summary: The first MacRobertson Shield was won by Australia in 1925, establishing the tournament as the premier international team event in croquet.
correctTheory.significance: Marked the beginning of international team competition in croquet
correctTheory.related_concepts: International croquet, team competition, tournament history

questions.citation: MacRobertson Shield Official Records, Croquet Association Archives

questions.question: What is the correct distance between hoops 1 and 2 on a standard court?

correctTheory.title: Court Setting and Measurements
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.summary: The standard distance between hoops 1 and 2 is set at 21 yards, a measurement crucial for proper court setup and consistent play.
correctTheory.significance: Essential for maintaining standardized court layouts worldwide
correctTheory.related_concepts: Court dimensions, hoop placement, setting specifications

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Law 2

questions.question: What is the recommended grip pressure for a stop shot?

correctTheory.title: Modern Stop Shot Technique
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Stop shot, grip pressure, shot control
correctTheory.summary: A 'medium to light' grip pressure is essential for executing stop shots effectively. This pressure allows the mallet to naturally rebound, unlike very firm or tight grips which can interfere with the shot mechanics.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental technique for accurate stop shot execution
correctTheory.related_concepts: Shot types, mallet control, basic techniques

questions.citation: Croquet Coaching Handbook, Chapter 2: Basic Shots

questions.question: In modern Association Croquet, what is the time limit for a standard tournament game?

correctTheory.title: Tournament Time Limits
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Time limits, tournament play, game management
correctTheory.summary: Standard tournament games are typically set at 3 hours, with specific rules for handling endings when time is called.
correctTheory.significance: Essential for tournament organization and play management
correctTheory.related_concepts: Tournament regulations, time management, competitive play

questions.citation: World Croquet Federation Tournament Regulations 2023

questions.question: According to MacRobertson Shield statistics (2010-2023), what point lead typically results in successful triple peel attempts?

correctTheory.title: Triple Peel Success Rates
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Triple peel statistics, risk assessment, tournament analysis
correctTheory.summary: Tournament statistics show that triple peels attempted with '8+ points' lead have significantly higher success rates, with over 70% completion in MacRobertson Shield matches from 2010-2023.
correctTheory.significance: Statistical basis for tactical decisions in high-level play
correctTheory.related_concepts: Risk assessment, game management, competitive strategy

questions.citation: MacRobertson Shield Statistical Analysis 2010-2023

questions.question: What is the optimal mallet weight for executing stop-shot peels in modern competitive play?

correctTheory.title: Equipment Optimization for Advanced Play
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Equipment selection, shot execution, technical optimization
correctTheory.summary: A mallet weight of 2.5-3.0 pounds provides optimal control and feedback for executing precise stop-shot peels.
correctTheory.significance: Equipment choice directly impacts advanced shot execution
correctTheory.related_concepts: Equipment specifications, shot technique, peeling control

correctTheory.title: Three-Ball Ending Tactics
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Endgame strategy, three-ball tactics, defensive play
correctTheory.summary: Defensive boundary play is recommended in three-ball endings to maintain control and limit opponent's options.
correctTheory.significance: Critical endgame strategy for tournament success
correctTheory.related_concepts: Endgame tactics, defensive strategy, game management

questions.question: In what situation should a stop-shot be preferred over a roll shot during a break?

correctTheory.title: Shot Selection Principles
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Shot selection, technical choices, break control
correctTheory.summary: Stop-shots are preferred when precise positioning is required, offering better control than roll shots.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental principle of shot selection and break control
correctTheory.related_concepts: Shot types, break control, technical decisions

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of 'guarding the boundary' in defensive play?

answers.answer: To prevent opponent's balls from leaving the court
To make opponent's shots at your balls more risky
To ensure your balls don't go out of bounds
To make it easier to start your next break

correctTheory.title: Defensive Play Tactics
correctTheory.author: Dr Ian Plummer
correctTheory.key_concepts: Boundary defense, tactical positioning, risk management
correctTheory.summary: Guarding the boundary makes opponent's shots risky because missed shots at boundary balls come back close to their target, allowing easy roquets.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental defensive tactic that influences opponent's shot selection
correctTheory.related_concepts: Defensive positioning, tactical play, risk assessment

questions.citation: Oxford Croquet - Defensive Play in Croquet

questions.question: What is the most important consideration when initiating a break in high-level tournament play?

answers.answer: Deciding which hoop to make first

correctTheory.title: Break Management in Elite Play
correctTheory.author: MacRobertson Shield Commentary
correctTheory.key_concepts: Break initiation, position assessment, tactical planning
correctTheory.summary: In high-level play, evaluating ball positions and opportunities is the crucial first step in break management, before planning specific shots or sequences.
correctTheory.significance: Foundation for successful break construction in tournament play
correctTheory.related_concepts: Break planning, position play, tactical assessment

questions.citation: MacRobertson Shield 2022 - Break Management Commentary

questions.question: In defensive play, what is the recommended distance from the boundary when 'guarding off the boundary'?

correctTheory.title: Boundary Defense Tactics
correctTheory.author: Dr Ian Plummer
correctTheory.key_concepts: Defensive positioning, boundary play, tactical placement
correctTheory.summary: Placing balls about 1 meter off the boundary allows for effective defensive play while maintaining the ability to send opponent's balls into court with stop-shots.
correctTheory.significance: Balances defensive safety with offensive potential
correctTheory.related_concepts: Defensive tactics, position play, break opportunities

questions.citation: Oxford Croquet - Defensive Play in Croquet

questions.question: What is the primary consideration when managing weather effects in break play during the MacRobertson Shield?

answers.answer: Adjusting shot selection based on conditions

correctTheory.title: Weather Impact on Break Play
correctTheory.author: MacRobertson Shield Commentary
correctTheory.key_concepts: Weather effects, shot adaptation, break management
correctTheory.summary: The primary consideration in managing weather effects is 'adjusting shot selection based on conditions', which is essential for maintaining control in varying weather situations.
correctTheory.significance: Critical for maintaining control in varying conditions
correctTheory.related_concepts: Break adaptation, weather management, risk assessment

questions.citation: MacRobertson Shield 2022 - Break Management Commentary

questions.question: What is the minimum distance a ball must move to be considered a stroke?

correctTheory.title: Stroke Definition
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Stroke rules, movement definition, game fundamentals
correctTheory.summary: A stroke is defined by '0 inches (any visible movement)' of the ball, ensuring clear and consistent application of rules in all situations.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of casting in croquet?

answers.answer: To find the best line for a shot

correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Shot preparation, aiming technique, pre-shot routine
correctTheory.summary: The primary purpose of casting is 'to find the best line for a shot'. This technique helps players visualize and confirm their intended line, improving accuracy.

correctTheory.title: Stop-Shot Technique
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Shot technique, swing mechanics, control principles

correctTheory.significance: Fundamental principle for executing stop-shots

questions.question: According to Wylie, what is the recommended counter to a Duffer tice?

correctTheory.title: Duffer Tice Counter-Tactics
correctTheory.author: Keith Wylie
correctTheory.summary: When facing a Duffer tice, K at U from B-baulk is the recommended counter, though RY still maintains a slight advantage.
correctTheory.significance: Important defensive tactic against aggressive openings
correctTheory.related_concepts: Opening tactics, defensive play, position control

questions.question: According to Wylie, what is the key principle for positioning ball U in the standard opening?

correctTheory.title: Standard Opening Principles
correctTheory.author: Keith Wylie
correctTheory.key_concepts: Opening tactics, court control, positional play
correctTheory.summary: Control of corner IV at the beginning of the game is advantageous because your balls tend to be behind the first break while your opponents' balls are in front of it.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental principle of opening strategy
correctTheory.related_concepts: Break building, tactical positioning, court control

questions.citation: Expert Croquet Tactics, Article 4: The Opening
